text:
MoU with administration to be signed for a 50-MW solar plant

Neyveli Lignite Corporation Ltd (NLC) is planning to set up a 50-MW solar power plant in Andaman and Nicobar Islands and is in discussions with the local administration , a top official said.

“We plan to sign an MoU with the administration there. We have provided a proposal which is under scrutiny,” P. Selvakumar, Director (Projects & Planning), NLC, told The Hindu .

“There is a hydel power station in Andamans, which is working only at 20 per cent capacity. We have proposed to put up a 20-MW plant at the facility to pump backwaters to the upper reservoir so that the hydel plant can utilise this recycled water,” he said.

The company has also invited global bids to set up two 65-MW solar power plants in Neyveli township and two more 65-MW solar plants in Rajasthan.

10-MW solar plant

NLC had set up a 10-MW solar plant in Neyveli last September.

“These solar plants will come up at our existing facilities and be connected to the grid. We have floated a global tender as we want to compete with the market which is price competitive. However, our first preference will be Indian companies,” Mr. Selvakumar said.

Neyveli Lignite Corporation is targeting to tap 4,000 MW of solar power.

In talks with other States

The Navratna company is also in talks with the governments of Karnataka, Telangana and Andhra Pradesh to set up 1,000 MW solar plants.

“We are also hoping to set up solar plants in Tamil Nadu. We will proceed first on whichever State gives us the go-ahead first.”
